data.text: Nepali sentences are structured differently than in English. Translating English sentences to Nepali and vice versa is like playing a sentence unscramble game because the sentences with their words will not be in the right order. So, we need to rearrange sentences before translating them in such a away that makes sense in the language we're translating to. Let's take a look at a sentence example.

I = ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§à, like = ‡§Æ‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§õ, and ‡§ó‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä‡§π‡§∞‡•Å = cars. The sentence "I like cars." was reorganized to "I cars like.", which makes no sense in English, and then it was translated to Nepali word by word. "I cars like." makes no sense in English but if you translated it to Nepali word by word then it makes perfect sense.

Nepali is a simple language for many reasons. Two of the reasons is that it has no capitalizations and no articles(the and a/an). The rule is that you remove and ignore every "the" in a sentence and change the article "a" or "an" to a quantitative number.  Let's take a look at an example:

There = ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§æ‡§Å. ‡§è‡§â‡§ü‡§æ = one, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§â = apple, and ‡§õ = is. As you can see above, "an" and been changed to "one" and it's using the same case. It is using the same case because uppercase or lowercase does not exist in Nepali, theres only single-case. It may not make grammatical sense in English but in Nepali it makes perfect sense. Just remember that some words in English doesn't exist in Nepali so you need to find an alternative way to say it.
Note: ‡§õ has multiple meanings in Nepali. It also means "I have". But the in context of the sentence above, it means "is".
